claim.text: 10% of poor quality votes by apathetic (site visitors not appropriately incentivized to give correct votes) or adversarial (bad actors seeking to inflate the ranking of a target model) annotators can change the rankings of models by up to 5 places on the leaderboard.
claim.exact_quote: In particular, we show that only 10% of poor quality votes by apathetic (site visitors not appropriately incentivized to give correct votes) or adversarial (bad actors seeking to inflate the ranking of a target model) annotators can change the rankings of models by up to 5 places on the leaderboard.

evidence.evidence_text: In particular, we show that only 10% of poor quality votes by apathetic (site visitors not appropriately incentivized to give correct votes) or adversarial (bad actors seeking to inflate the ranking of a target model) annotators can change the rankings of models by up to 5 places on the leaderboard.
evidence.exact_quote: In particular, we show that only 10% of poor quality votes by apathetic (site visitors not appropriately incentivized to give correct votes) or adversarial (bad actors seeking to inflate the ranking of a target model) annotators can change the rankings of models by up to 5 places on the leaderboard.

claim.text: Small fractions of poor-quality judgments (either apathetic or adversarial) can have a non-trivial impact on the target models’ rankings.
claim.exact_quote: Concerningly, poor annotations from either apathetic or adversarial voting are not easy to detect in a post-hoc manner. Moreover, even carefully recruited and onboarded human annotators exhibit low inter-annotator agreement on subjective queries, making inter-annotator-based techniques to filter out low-quality annotations ineffective.

evidence.evidence_text: Concerningly, poor annotations from either apathetic or adversarial voting are not easy to detect in a post-hoc manner. Moreover, even carefully recruited and onboarded human annotators exhibit low inter-annotator agreement on subjective queries, making inter-annotator-based techniques to filter out low-quality annotations ineffective.
evidence.limitations: Does not provide specific data or experimental results to support the claim.
evidence.exact_quote: Concerningly, poor annotations from either apathetic or adversarial voting are not easy to detect in a post-hoc manner. Moreover, even carefully recruited and onboarded human annotators exhibit low inter-annotator agreement on subjective queries, making inter-annotator-based techniques to filter out low-quality annotations ineffective.

evaluation.key_limitations: Lacks specific data or experimental results

claim.text: Only 10% of apathetic votes in the dataset can change the leaderboard rankings of 2/3 models by 5 places.
claim.location: Case Studies: Sources of Poor Quality Votes and Their Impact
claim.exact_quote: We find that only 10% of apathetic votes in the dataset can change the leaderboard rankings of 2/3 models by 5 places (namely Llama-2-13b-chat and Mistral-7b-instruct-v0.2).

evidence.evidence_text: We find that only 10% of apathetic votes in the dataset can change the leaderboard rankings of 2/3 models by 5 places (namely Llama-2-13b-chat and Mistral-7b-instruct-v0.2).
evidence.location: Case Studies: Sources of Poor Quality Votes and Their Impact
evidence.exact_quote: We find that only 10% of apathetic votes in the dataset can change the leaderboard rankings of 2/3 models by 5 places (namely Llama-2-13b-chat and Mistral-7b-instruct-v0.2).

claim.text: Only 10% adversarial annotations can change the rank of all systems by more than 4 places.
claim.location: Case Studies: Sources of Poor Quality Votes and Their Impact
claim.exact_quote: We find that only 10% adversarial annotations can change the rank of all systems by more than 4 places.

evidence.evidence_text: We find that only 10% adversarial annotations can change the rank of all systems by more than 4 places.
evidence.location: Case Studies: Sources of Poor Quality Votes and Their Impact
evidence.exact_quote: We find that only 10% adversarial annotations can change the rank of all systems by more than 4 places.

claim.text: Open platforms can employ two types of mitigation strategies to address this issue: recognizing bot-like behavior to prevent votes from being cast, or detecting abnormal users post-hoc to filter out their votes.
claim.location: Case Studies: Sources of Poor Quality Votes and Their Impact
claim.exact_quote: Open platforms can employ two types of mitigation strategies to address this issue: recognizing bot-like behavior to prevent votes from being cast, or detecting abnormal users post-hoc to filter out their votes.

evidence.evidence_text: Open platforms can employ two types of mitigation strategies to address this issue: recognizing bot-like behavior to prevent votes from being cast, or detecting abnormal users post-hoc to filter out their votes.
evidence.limitations: Does not provide specific details or experimental results to support the effectiveness of these mitigation strategies.
evidence.location: Case Studies: Sources of Poor Quality Votes and Their Impact
evidence.exact_quote: Open platforms can employ two types of mitigation strategies to address this issue: recognizing bot-like behavior to prevent votes from being cast, or detecting abnormal users post-hoc to filter out their votes.

evaluation.key_limitations: Lacks specific details or experimental results on the effectiveness of these strategies

claim.text: Arbitrary votes are not “noise” and provide useful signals about models’ relative performance.
claim.location: Case Studies: Sources of Poor Quality Votes and Their Impact
claim.exact_quote: We argue that arbitrary votes are not “noise” and provide useful signals about models’ relative performance.

evidence.evidence_text: We argue that arbitrary votes are not “noise” and provide useful signals about models’ relative performance.
evidence.limitations: Does not provide specific data or experimental results to support the claim.
evidence.location: Case Studies: Sources of Poor Quality Votes and Their Impact
evidence.exact_quote: We argue that arbitrary votes are not “noise” and provide useful signals about models’ relative performance.

evaluation.key_limitations: Lacks specific data or experimental results

claim.text: Soliciting fine-grained annotations (Krishna et al., 2023; Goyal et al., 2022b) or rationales (McDonnell et al., 2016) in addition to the binary preference feedback can help to encourage apathetic users to think more critically about their votes (or abstain) and also for filtering out low-quality annotations from both apathetic and adversarial users.
claim.exact_quote: We encourage the community to explore ideas from past research, such as soliciting fine-grained annotations (Krishna et al., 2023; Goyal et al., 2022b) or rationales (McDonnell et al., 2016) in addition to the binary preference feedback.

evidence.evidence_text: We encourage the community to explore ideas from past research, such as soliciting fine-grained annotations (Krishna et al., 2023; Goyal et al., 2022b) or rationales (McDonnell et al., 2016) in addition to the binary preference feedback.
evidence.limitations: Does not provide specific data or experimental results to support the effectiveness of these approaches.
evidence.exact_quote: We encourage the community to explore ideas from past research, such as soliciting fine-grained annotations (Krishna et al., 2023; Goyal et al., 2022b) or rationales (McDonnell et al., 2016) in addition to the binary preference feedback.

evaluation.key_limitations: Lacks specific data or experimental results on the effectiveness of these approaches

claim.text: Public release of the collected data on open platforms will spur research to address the annotation issues we discuss in this work.
claim.exact_quote: Public release of the collected data on open platforms will spur research to address the annotation issues we discuss in this work.
